direction.raw_text: . MINUTES LATER - NIGHT A SHORT MONTAGE as the twenty-one volunteers mount the dais and are fitted with their game gear: The assistants undo the heavy-duty snap locks and split open the ski-boot-like plastic modules on the back table. Inside, resting in a lining of dense foam, are what look almost like living kidneys: the MetaFlesh Game-Pods. Coiled in each boot toe is the Y-shaped, multi-player UmbyCord that comes with each pod, a split twelve-foot connector cord that resembles an umbilical cord, twisted, translucent, blue and red veiny vessels running just below the surface. The volunteers watch in hushed reverence, as though about to receive communion. The game-pods are gingerly lifted out of their cases. The UmbyCords are uncoiled and plugged into ports in the back of the game-pods. The shirts, blouses, and jackets of the volunteers are lifted at the back to reveal their owners' bioports, which are small, soft-plastic, flesh-coloured permanent spinal jacks positioned just above the belt line. Twenty-two folding chairs are placed in a circle on the dais. As each volunteer has his UmbyCord plugged into his bioport, he takes one of the seats and places his quivering, rippling game-pod, now connected directly to his nervous system, on his lap. The last chair is taken by Allegra Geller, who is fussed i over and settled by Levi as she unpacks her own master game- pod with exaggerated delicacy and is then ported in to the players on either side of her. We END the short MONTAGE with the security guard, Pikul, standing with arms folded near the church's side door, watching the proceedings with fascination. A loud knocking at the door forces Pikul to turn away from the action on the dais. He walks over to the door and opens it. A hyper, exasperated fan almost tumbles into the church. Pikul immediately raises his electronic wand and bars his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold it. Not so fast. In response, the fan thrusts a card at him. Pikul takes the card, a complex invitation card which includes a holographic photo of the fan under which floats his name, Joel Dichter. Dichter anxiously looks past Pikul into the depths of the church, nervously adjusting the vinyl case slung over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, god. I hope I'm not too late. Did I miss the port-in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just the first wave. You can be part of the second wave. (rereads the invitation)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joel Dichter. Put your arms up. I have to scan you. Metal and heavy synthetics can't come in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A weapons check?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More for recording devices. Lotta money invested in these games. Industrial espionage happens. What's in this case?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I brought my game-pod. It's got original Marway tissue architecture. It's kind of obsolete but I was hoping,... (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: even though I couldn't afford the Antenna Fifteen upgrade, I figured out a method of virtual porting that I thought might... Pikul uses his wand to scan the vinyl case, then opens the zipper and feels around. In the case is a more solid, rubbery version of the new MetaFlesh pods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't need it tonight. Everything's provided for. Dichter suddenly spots Geller on the dais. He almost faints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Migod! Is that who I think it is? .PIKUL (with paternal pride) Yeah, that's her. She's something, isn't she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But why would a star like her come to a product seminar in a little one-horse town like this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is where the real people live, Joel. Her real fans, like you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well, you said it. Just like me. Dichter has scanned OK. Pikul waves him into the church to join the spectators who will form the second wave and re- locks the door. On the dais, in the center of the circle of linked game players, Levi nods at Geller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything's in order. Are you ready, Allegra?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. This is my favourite part. There is giddy laughter in the room. Geller looks at every player-in the circle as Levi steps down off the platform and retires to the far edge of the small, watching throng.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm ready to download eXistenZ by Antenna Research into you all now. I'm warning you, it's going to be a wild ride, but don't panic no matter what happens. I'll see you all back here in no time at all. Now the giddy laughter goes a touch nervous, uncertain, but it's too late. Geller depresses a nipple-like protuberance on the game-pod on her lap, and all the players close their eyes and go rigid, like members of a seance who have suddenly been contacted by the spirit world. The pods in their laps begin a rhythmic, peristaltic rippling. At the edge of the crowd, Pikul sidles up to Levi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She seems to be very shy. It never occurred to me that a big star would be shy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She spends most of her time alone in a room designing her games. I think she'd like it best if she never had to show them to anybody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? She doesn't enjoy all the adulation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hates having to port in with her fans. It's too intimate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why does she do it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We make her do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By "we" you mean, the game company, Antenna Research?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what I mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you with us or did an independent security company send you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me? Oh, I'm with your own management training program. (shows him a card) I want to end up in marketing and public relations. (holds up security wand) The only thing I know about security is how to switch this thing on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, for example, we've spent a fortune developing eXistenZ, but we all know it's a risky project. She might have to make changes. It's the only way we can convince her that there might be a problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A problem with her new game?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: eXistenZ is a lot more than a game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, right, it's a game system. I heard that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we're worried that it's too intellectual, too complex, too weird, too artsy. That argument ; never bothers her until she faces her fans. She hates to be rejected in the flesh, so we make her come out sometimes to take the heat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 4 I've heard that she's very sensitive. A strange, choral humming begins to fill the church. Pikul and Levi turn their attention to the dais, where the fans rock and sway with the pulsing of the pods in their laps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are they doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the new Antenna Research theme song. We thought this would be a good way to launch it. Everybody who plays eXistenZ is going to be very familiar with that tune. Haltingly, but gamely, Pikul tries to hum along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Catchy. Levi helps him out, and soon the whole room is humming along happily, warmed by the Antenna Research corporate theme song. The whole room, that is, except for Joel Dichter, who, at the edge of the dais, is more concerned with fumbling around in the vinyl pod-case hanging from his shoulder. In the case, we watch as Dichter tears open his obsolete game-pod to reveal a bizarre weapon, a pistol made of bone and gristle, almost like the half-decayed body of a small mammal - whose snout is the barrel, whose rigid hind leg is the trigger. Dichter takes his weapon out of its case, shakes off a few gelatinous strips of game-pod flesh, and steps up onto the dais. Pikul is the first to notice this. He glances at Levi, who's still blissed out and humming, then launches himself awkwardly through the crowd. Now in the middle of the circle, Dichter makes his way towards the blissfully unsuspecting Geller, raising his weapon as he goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Death to eXistenZ! Death to Antenna Research! Death to the demoness Allegra Geller!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Don't do it! Dichter turns to see Pikul stumbling through the small crowd, scrambling onto the dais. Distracted, Dichter hurriedly raises his weapon again and fires it at Geller. The first shot hits her in the shoulder and spins her off her chair, which collapses over her and takes the second bullet on its seat rim. The circle of players on the dais moans as one, swoons and jostles: they are all feeling the neural surge of Geller's traumatized nervous system. Peeking out from under her folding chair, Geller's eyes are wide with fear and confusion. She clutches her shoulder without being aware of it. Blood seeps in between her fingers Now Levi and his two assistants scramble onto the platform to get at Dichter, who fires wildly, hitting two of the players nearest Geller. The circle of players immediately goes spastic, screaming and twitching and dropping to the ground and writhing. Many of them are clutching their shoulders in the same spot as Geller, sympathy pain transmitting through their UmbyCords. Pikul manages to tackle Dichter, then starts whacking at him with the security wand. Dichter twists around and raises his weapon at Pikul, who immediately backs off in terror. But before Dichter can pull the trigger, the two assistants produce small, normal pistols from hidden holsters and empty their clips into the prostrate Dichter. Dichter manages to squeeze off one last shot at the approaching Jevi, hitting him squarely in the chest. Levi goes down and is lost amongst the jostling feet. The watching fans pile onto the dais and begin to help the players unplug from the game-pods which are obviously causing them distress. Three of the players attack the dying Dichter, dragging their game-pods after them, kicking at whatever part of him they can find in the confused mass of bodies. in the turmoil, Pikul is knocked to the ground. Amid the stamping, sliding feet, he finds himself lying across the stricken-Levi. Levi clutches Pikul desperately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get her out of here! Save her! There might be more of them! Go on!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me? Me take her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (urgent, pleading) We have enemies in our own house. Trust no one. Trust no one... The wide-eyed Pikul scrambles to his feet and promptly trips over the all-but-dead Dichter. He falls painfully to his knees, struggles up again, and finds the bizarre bone gun in his hand. Pikul stares at it, fascinated, horrified. He turns back to Levi, but Levi's eyes are rolling back as he loses consciousness. The two assistants are making their way towards them through the shoving, shuffling throng, guns cocked, faces set hard. Panicked, Pikul jams the bone gun into his suit pocket and jumps off the platform, wildly looking around for Geller. She and her chair have slipped off the dais in a heap only a few feet away, and she is in several kinds of agony. Pikul unports her, which immediately brings her some relief and a lot of clarity. Pikul wards off a couple of fans with one arm, screams at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's coming with me! I'm responsible for her! She's supposed to come with me! To his surprise, Geller laughs a dazed, hearty laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I? With you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quietly, firmly) Yeah, you're coming with me. Pikul pulls her to her feet, but she immediately dives back to the floor to find her game-pod and UmbyCord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (suddenly near hysteria) I can't lose this! I can't lose this! She finds the game-pod still under the folding chair, a bit flattened on one side but in one piece. She grabs the game- pod and its UmbyCord and stuffs them into her MetaFlesh pod case which has been knocked to the edge of the dais. As she clutches it to her, Pikul takes her hand and hauls her through the crowd, which is now spilling off the overcrowded dais and clutching at Geller fitfully, like Velcro. They head for the door, fighting everybody off as though they might be lethal. As they leave through the side door, Pikul sees five or six fans, shrieking like monkeys, still stomping and kicking the body of Dichter viciously, hysterically, while Levi's two assistants carry him to the safety of the church's apse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pikul and Geller spew out of the doorway and find themselves standing alone in the weedy parking lot of the church. The church itself stands isolated on a country road just outside a town which is not much more than two gas stations and a crossroad. Pikul and Geller look around wildly. The vehicles in the parking lot are country, pickup trucks, rusted vans, 4x4s. Across the road, aloof, maybe too high-class for the parking lot, sits a Land Rover Defender 110, the one with the roof cage and the seven seats and the winch hanging off the front. Geller gestures towards the Defender.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's take my limo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why no?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't trust the driver!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You drive, idiot! They cross the road and jump in the Defender. Frances, the driver, sixtyish, a retired lady farmer who moonlights, is apprehensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the commotion, Miss Geller? Say, are you all right? What's goin' on in there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need this vehicle, and we need it without you. But with the keys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't do that. I can't abandon my vehicle. Geller pulls the weird gun out of an astonished Pikul's pocket. She points it at Frances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out, Frances. You can say you were hijacked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll take more than a dead squirrel to get me out of this seat. Geller fires two shots. One rips a hole in Frances's headrest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (getting out of her seat) You have to push the shift lever down to get it into reverse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Frances. They drive off down the country road, leaving Frances in the dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pikul drives. He can see why the limo is an off-road vehicle: the road is terrible, dirt and gravel, stutter potholes and sharp ridges, the occasional fallen tree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (manic, scared) I normally like the countryside, don't you? Normally, the country is relaxing and calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only if you don't really know what's going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is great stress and anger and violence in the countryside. Thousands of life forms all screaming ME ME ME and trying to kill and dominate and devour the other life forms. It's terrifying and exhausting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I like the countryside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good, `cause you might end up spending a lot of time here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. If you go back home to the city, they'll probably be waiting for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. My assassins. They'd want to have a little talk with you about where I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was hoping that was just one crazy guy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear the way he screamed at me? He wasn't alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody likes a conspiracy. It's more satisfying than just one crazy guy doing one crazy thing. Geller goes silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, what are we going to do out here? Do you know your way around? You know any country people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not country people. Games people. The countryside's full of games development people, project co- ordinators, little factories - you name it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's weird. I never knew that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The city's full of bad microwaves, bad thermals, bad electro-optics. You can't shield from it anymore. You can't get true readings. The whole industry moved out of the city years ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you know your way around. We can hide out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe. But it seems I have some enemies I didn't know I had. "Death to Allegra Geller." How'd you like to hear somebody with a gun screaming, "Death to Ted Pikul"?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow. (reflective pause; then) Hey, how'd you know my name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (indicating his name tag) You're labelled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Yeah. (PAUSE) How did you know how to fire that, gun? I've never seen anything like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It has a trigger. I pulled it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I see it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later. I think I'm gonna use it in my next game. If there ever is a next game. Pikul glances at her. He hits a pothole and she bounces around in her seat, exposing her far shoulder to him. Her shirt is soaked with blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Migod, you're bleeding. I forgot you got hit. There is an urgent buzzing from somewhere in Pikul's breast pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my pink-fone. I'm not sure I should answer it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Answer it. Pikul pulls the pink-fone - it's soft surgical plastic, palm-sized - out of his pocket. When he squeezes it open, a diffuse pink light swells up from deep inside it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted Pikul. (PAUSE) What happened? Some fan went crazy and started shooting up the place. I don't know why. He was just nuts. Allegra Geller? She's with me. We're OK. Yeah. Yeah. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're kidding me. You're kidding me! God. 1 can't believe it. I can't do that. No, how can I do that? Well, I'm not really sure where we are because... Geller grabs the pink-tone from him. She fumbles around with it, trying to find the power button. She accidentally summons up a read-out, which she pauses to look at. What she sees makes her glance up at Pikul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Can I have my pink-tone back? Geller finds the power button and pushes it. The pink inner light flutters out. She unceremoniously throws the pink-tone out the window. It lands in a rain ditch full of frogs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you do that for? That was our lifeline to civilization.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was a rangefinder. As long as you have that, they know where you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They? You mean head office?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean anybody. (PAUSE) I heard what Levi said to you. He said, "We have enemies in our own house." He said it as he was dying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think he died. I mean, do you? I think he maybe fainted... Maybe he went unconscious...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was Alex Kindred, head of publicity and marketing, at Antenna HQ... (WISTFUL) .on that very expensive pink- fone you threw away. (DEEP SIGH) He said that some bizarre fanatical group called the Anti- eXistenZialists has put a price of 5 million dollars on your head, payable to anybody who kills you. It's been released to all the media now. Everybody knows about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anti-existentialists?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Anti-eXistenZialists. Capital
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: capital Z. They somehow found out about eXistenZ and they want to kill you for creating it. They say that the eXistenZ game system will "finally destroy reality", or something totally nuts like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It makes sense to you? You're not suprised?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear things. It's hard to surprise me. (PAUSE) And what else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kindred said that I'm your bodyguard and the company is holding me totally responsible for your safety.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pikul, why don't you have a gun with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not armed. They told me you were my security but you have no weaponry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who told you that? I'm just a marketing trainee. My clinic master thought I'd learn something about marketing if I moonlighted as a security guard on one of your test previews.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck. I'm marked for death and they send me on the road with a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nerd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (realization setting in) Jesus! Marked for death!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't sweat it, Pikul. I'll handle it. We just have to disappear for a while. And right now, we have to stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We do? Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So we can have an intimate moment together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The intimate moment involves Pikul digging the bullet out of I Geller's shoulder with a Swiss Army knife while kneeling in front of the idling Defender's headlights. Pikul'is being squeamish and not getting the job done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon. If you're gonna do it, do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He grits his teeth and digs in with a bit more gusto. Something yellow and white, like a kernel of corn, flips out of her wound and onto the road's shredding asphalt. Pikul feels around for it, finds it, holds it up to the light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got it. Wow. Did somebody bite you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I just dug out of you. It's a tooth. A human tooth. Pikul holds the tooth out to her, but she just glances at it, then rummages around in her MetaFlesh game-pod bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lemme see that weirdo pistol. Geller pulls the strange weapon out of the bag. After a moment of study, she expertly pops the magazine out of the grip. The gristly magazine is packed with teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yep. The bullets are human teeth. Look - this one's got a cavity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That thing was designed to get past any kind of metal or synthetics detector. It's all flesh and bone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose the smaller caliber pistols would have to fire baby teeth. The tooth fairy could go I into the arms business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That guy really came there tonight just to kill you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amazing, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We follow the Defender as it parks outside the Salmon Falls Motel. Pikul jumps out carrying two paper bags of Perky Pat's takeout. He knees the truck door shut and walks over to motel door 5.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inside the very basic motel room, Pikul sits hypnotized, reverentially watching Geller as he obsessively packs the greasy remains of their Perky Pat burgers into the smallest possible paper bundle. Geller is sitting in the middle of her twin bed, her pod before her on a hotel towel which is draped over her lap, UmbyCord jacked into her bioport, a second towel slipping off her shoulders leaving her almost naked, her shoulder wound livid in the 25-watt light of the night table lamp. Her hands twitch delicately over the surface of the pod like insect antennae, so delicately that we are not sure that she is actually touching the pod. Her eyes are half-closed, and she is obviously in some kind of trance-like, ecstatic state. Finally, she comes out of it and unplugs her UmbyCord, discretely rearranging her towels in the process. She sighs and speaks, not exactly to Pikul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole gamesworld is in a kind of trance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I remember you said that at the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People are prepared to accept so little. They're in a'cage formed out of their own limited (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: expectations. They have no idea what amazing things could be theirs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where were you just now? What were you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a worried frown) I was wandering through eXistenZ - the new system, I mean. (a shy, sexy smile) I like it in there. Of course, without another player you're only a tourist. It's frustrating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why won't you let me contact Antenna? They've got to be going crazy, wondering what's happened to you. I mean, it's not like we've done something wrong. We just ran because we didn't know how many of them there were, right? I think we owe it to Antenna to let them know you're all right, to get them to send somebody to help you who knows what he's doing... And besides, I can't... I can't just keep doing this, whatever it is, you know, forever, not having any idea when it's going to be... Geller gets up and goes over to Pikul. She pulls up his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, what are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's your bioport? Don't tell me you were never fitted. I can't believe it. Pikul shrugs his shirt back down, starts tucking it in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I was never fitted with a bioport. What do you care?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're hoping to get into the biz and you've never played one of my games. You've never played any game. That means you have no idea % what a genius I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My clinic master told me I don't need to play a game to know how to sell it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullshit. Posturing. You don't play my games, you don't work for Antenna Research, I'll make sure of that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I've been dying to play your games. But I have this - phobia about having my body penetrated - surgically. You know what I mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not so sure I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Getting a bioport fitted... I dunno. I can't do it. It's too freaky. Makes my skin crawl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, c'mon. They just pop your spine with a little hydro-gun. Shoot the port-plug into it. They do it at malls, like getting your ears pierced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, sure. With only an infinitesimal chance of permanent spinal paralysis. I've read all about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your chosen profession, geek. She pauses, then moves very close to him. She breathes her words slowly, intimately, into his ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's an intimacy involved in playing eXistenZ that is beyond description. It has to be experienced. And frankly, the two-player version is the most exquisitely intense. Wouldn't you like to play with me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (his resolve is crumbling) Well, yeah, of course, but... Let me, uh, let me call Antenna...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a gentle threat) They wouldn't want to talk to you if they knew you had never had a bioport installed. It's company policy, you know. They want you to be passionate about your work. (VERY SEDUCTIVE) Besides, once you're ported, there's no end to the games you can play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't seriously want to play games now. Not here. Not while we're being hunted down by crazy people. _ Geller sighs, then switches into her explaining-the-facts- of-life-to-a-child mode.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cradling her pod) My baby here took a huge hit in the church, Pikul. You see how she's quivering? Pikul takes a look. The pod is, in fact, quivering like a terrified hamster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It... she, yes, she's quivering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When those UmbyCords got ripped out of her in the church, ripped (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: out just as the game architecture was being downloaded from her to all those slave pods... that's a very vulnerable time for her. She could be crying out for help right here, right now. (CHOKING UP) The only way I can tell if everything's OK - the game's not been contaminated, the pod, my baby, is not about to be crippled for life because of my negligence - the only way is to play eXistenZ with somebody friendly. Are you friendly, or are you not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, all right. (he might have found a way
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's do it... let's do it now. Let me see. (checks his watch) To get an illegal, unregistered bioport installed at about midnight - we just drive up to your local country gas station, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Defender is parked by the pumps. A gangly pump attendant - his name, embroidered on his overalls, seems to be Gas - fills the truck as Pikul and Geller hover nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything else I can do for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Gas, you could check your bioport-plugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The what? The sparkplugs?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard me. My friend here has a bioport problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bioport, now, that's a sort of a hole in your spine, isn't it? Lotta assholes `round here, but that's generally it. I don't know why you'd be talking to me about that, lady. Geller smiles a knowing smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure you do. Gas looks at her closely for the first time. His eyes widen in disbelief. He pulls a greasy wallet out of his overalls and flips out the card holders. Amongst various family photos, hot rod photos, fishing photos, is a photo of Allegra Geller clipped from a glossy magazine. Under the photo is the legend "Genius In A Game-Pod". Gas takes her hand in his and kisses it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allegra Geller. You changed my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pikul sits on a mouldy, greasy, plump, wingback chair in the corner of the gas-station garage, watching Gas balance shakily on one leg as he puts on a fresh set of overalls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was your life like before?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before it was changed by Allegra Geller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I operated a gas station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you still operate a gas station, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only on the most pathetic level of reality. Geller's work liberated me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liberated?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you ever play her game ArtGod? One word, capital A, capital G?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have a bioport, remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Thou, the player of the game, art God." Very spiritual. Funny, too. God, the artist. The mechanic. (chuckles to himself) Funny. Gas zips up his fresh overalls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those are sterile, are they?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to worry. They way they set things up, you could fire in a bioport in a slaughterhouse and not generate an infection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why the clean overalls?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a mental thing. Helps me focus. The one thing you don't want to do is miss with the stud- finder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, the mechanic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gas slides open a drawer of his red metal mechanic's rolling toolbox and pulls out a greasy device that looks like a carbon-fibre voltage meter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We call this thing a stud-finder.' It locates the spot on your spine where the x intersects with the y. We don't want to be even a micron out of whack. That's when you get troubles. It's a little radar/sonar/laser thingee. Marks you with a special range-finding dye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never say dye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lift up your shirt and turn around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the heat of the summer night, game-pod case still slung over her shoulder, Geller wanders around the periphery of the gas station, touching things - trees, the ground, grass - at random, her expression suggesting that everything she sees is amazing and delightful and slightly disturbing, like someone who has wandered into a sculpture garden where everything is perfect in every detail except that everything is made out of bronze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gas pulls the trigger on the stud-finder, then removes it from Pikul's back. We see a small purple flower-mark, like the kind that marks sides of beef, on the skin over Pikul's spine just above the belt line. Pikul stands up from his kneeling position on the wingback chair. He stretches, twists. Everything seems to be all right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, that didn't hurt, did it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't expect that to hurt. I expect the next part to hurt. Gas pulls the bioport insertion gun out of another drawer, this time a locked wooden one bolted under his metal-topped work bench. It is a scary thing, like a hydraulic jack designed by Giger, only smaller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, that's what I expect will hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never crippled anyone yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many have you done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three. Well, you'll be the third.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are close on a bizarre insect which sits unsteadily on the chrome of a gas pump handle. Geller's hand comes into frame and gently eases the creature into its palm. Geller floats her hand closer to her face and studies the creature with an expression of rapture on her face. The insect is large, praying mantis-sized, and it has two heads, neither of which seems to know how to deal with the other one. Each time it attempts to move, it falls over in an awkward heap because its legs are all different sizes and shapes. It beats its large, papery wings wildly in order to pull itself upright and then begins the whole clumsy process all over again. Eventually, its wing action lifts it off Geller's hand - more by accident than will, it seems - and the creature disappears in the darkness surrounding the gas pumps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Geller enters the garage and sees Pikul with his back to the wall of the service bay and a large wrench in his hand, poised and threatening. Gas stands twenty feet away, his insertion gun at the ready. A Mexican standoff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on, Gas?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, he's acting like I'm attackin' him. People usually pay me.to do this, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. All two of them. As you can see, I've decided not to have a bioport installed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Geller walks over to Pikul and puts her face quite close to his. He watches her lips move from the corner of his eye. They. are full and moist and convincing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is it, you see. This is the cage I was talking about, the cage of your own making which keeps you trapped and pacing about in the smallest possible space forever. Break out of your cage, Pikul. Break out now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOMENTS LATER - NIGHT Wearing mechanic's work gloves, Gas fires in the bioport plug. Its impact knocks the breath out of Pikul, like being kicked in the spine; he can't even scream. When Gas pulls the insertion device away from Pikul's back, we see the glossy plastic head of the bioport plug. It's surrounded by a small, angry-looking volcano of rashy, irritated flesh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That swelling doesn't last for long. Tomorrow, you won't even notice it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love it. Great. Pikul tries to get up from the wingback chair and promptly collapses into the arms of Geller and Gas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on? I can't walk!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The procedure comes with its own epidural, just like when you have a baby. Kinda like instant paralysis from the waist down? That's why it didn't hurt you. It'll wear off in about twenty minutes. As they ease Pikul into a sitting position in the chair, Gas almost drops the insertion gun which he has been holding in one hand. He leans it against the wingback chair, and Pikul notices blood and flecks of skin on Gas's work gloves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're looking more like a butcher than a mechanic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Things do get kinda confused these days, don't they? I'm gonna go wash up. You two make yourselves at home. Gas strides off towards the washroom with an air of great satisfaction. Geller eases her game-pod out of its case and starts to attach its two-player, Y-shaped UmbyCord to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't have to wait for the swelling to go down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to port into me? While I'm paralysed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wanted to play my game, didn't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I did, and I do, but... Here? Now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's an instant-on world, isn't it? She lifts up his shirt to reveal the new bioport. It already looks a bit less angry than it did before. Geller caresses it, prods it, plays with it. Then she takes out a little bottle of WD-40 and sprays it around and into the port.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that for? It feels cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: New ports are sometimes a bit tight. Wouldn't want to hurt you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come bioports don't get infected? I mean, they open right into your body...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to what you're saying, Pikul. Don't be ludicrous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you think you could call me Ted?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe afterwards. Geller gently works her UmbyJack into Pikul's bioport. She locks her eyes onto his, then squeezes her game-pod's ON teat. Instantly, her pod convulses and begins to flash and spark and crackle. White electronic smoke seeps from its crevices and a kind of bioelectronic fat sputters from its pores. Geller leaps up from the arm of the chair and rips her UmbyJack out of Pikul's spine. He can't feel it, but the furious force of her move twists him in his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit, Pikul! I can't believe this! I trusted you and you blew my pod! You must have neural- surged!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I jacked you into my pod and you obviously panicked. Now it's totally fucked! This is a disaster!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .. I was nervous, but I didn't panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was forced to trust you and you panicked and you neural-surged, and you blew my pod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can get a new pod...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (her heart is breaking) Pikul, in this pod is the only, the original version of eXistenZ, an entire game system that cost thirty-eight million to develop, not including pre-release marketing costs. And I'm locked outside of my own game! I can't get it out, or me in!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you serious? This is the only version that exists?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Security is everything these days. It's the only one and its stuck inside and it's your fault. Geller uses her sleeve to clean the drool off the pod with tragic gentleness, as though it were an injured child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (fighting back tears) I've devoted my five most passionate years to this strange little creature. And I've never regretted it, Pikul, because I knew that it was the only thing that could give my life any meaning...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But why is it my fault? I'm telling you, I didn't, I did not neural-surge. I didn't. I didn't feel any surging. Gas strolls into the garage, still wearing his work gloves, which now hold an agricultural-looking shotgun. It is levelled at Geller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It isn't your fault. It's my fault. Pikul looks at Gas in disbelief. His feet begin to writhe in circles, but he still can't get out of the chair; Geller backs away from Gas, clutching her pod protectively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no, Gas, not you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't try to use that bioport again, `cept maybe for a toaster or something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're worth a lot of money. If you're dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I'm talking about. It's all over the countryside. Five million for her dead body. No questions asked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, but... she changed your life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yup. And now I'm gonna change hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But wait... Why did you install a bad port into me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seems there's a big bonus for killing Allegra Geller's latest game, or whatever it is. I think I just did that, didn't I? Geller decides to try another tack. She stops backing away and begins to slowly approach Gas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But can you kill a person? Can you do that, Gas? Can you kill me? Hide my body. Contact the crazies. Trust them to pay up. Hand over my now-decaying, fucking grotesque corpse. Really expect them to hand over 5 mil cash? Don't you ever go to the fuckin' movies?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like your script. I want to be in it. Gas cocks his shotgun. He's really going to do it. Except that Pikul shoots him right in the mastoid bone, just behind the ear, with the bioport insertion gun. The back of Gas's skull shatters and he goes down hard. Pikul drops the gun and launches himself out of his chair. He falls to his knees beside Gas's body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God, I think he's dead. I thought I could just distract him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did distract him. (to Gas's body) Plug your toaster into that hole, corpse!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Geller drives. Pikul hangs on in the passenger seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wanted to kill you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's two people in one day who wanted to actually kill you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never been more popular.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allegra, we need help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. I've got to get this pod fixed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Defender winds its way up a heavily wooded mountain road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Defender turns off a dirt road and rumbles through an open gate. The stone gateposts bear a coy rustic sign which reads, CALEDON SKI CLUB - PRIVATE ROAD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going skiing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing in the countryside is what it seems. It's all appearance versus reality, and the reality here is something unique.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Defender pulls up beside the chalet-style ski clubhouse. As they get out of the truck, the same bizarre insect that Geller was playing with the night before lands on the truck's side mirror, narrowly missing Pikul as it flops around in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at that huge bug. It's got two heads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They breed them here. They're not supposed to get away. They get out and walk towards the clubhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if somebody comes up here and really wants to ski?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody actually physically skis any more, Pikul. You know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've watched some ski shows. Downhill racing, Austrian Alps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pikul and Geller enter the clubhouse. There is nobody around. It looks like a real ski clubhouse, complete with racks of ski pants and ski boots. But when Pikul examines the goods, he can see that they're old and cracked and falling apart. They've been there for years. ` A man comes out of a back room, early sixties, authoritarian air, eastern-European. He is Kiri Vinokur, and he lights up when he sees Geller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My darling Allegra. I am so pleased to see you here. They embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kiri Vinokur, this is my bodyguard, Ted Pikul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, yes, I heard the ridiculous story about this fatwa against you. The company is desperately trying to find you. Is it really serious? Are you in danger?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I'm her bodyguard, then she's in grave danger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There have been a couple of attempts on my life already.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! That's unbearable. The company must stop this. They owe you every kind of protection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know if they can do anything about it. It seems to be open season on me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you will be safe here, I can assure you of that. I will contact Antenna right away and have them send some people to come and collect you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kiri, no, don't. You mustn't let anybody know we're here unless you have to. I can't be sure that Antenna is completely safe for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. Yes. The company draws many eccentric people into its fold. You can hide in one of the guest chalets. As long as you like. I will make sure you get fresh towels... Geller pats her game-pod case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .and make sure I don't lose everything I have in here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the strange atmosphere of the workshop chalet, Vinokur is taking Geller's pod apart. It is more like surgery on an alien life form than computer electronics. The room feels like a weird combination of a hi-tech operating room and a woodworking class. A cherubic middle-aged man - Landry - who looks more like a farmhand than an electronics technician, assists Vinokur as he works.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you port into?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pikul's bioport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? That's what did all the damage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was a flawed installation - my first. It... it neural-surged. Allegra says you can fix it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It fried some very expensive nerve boards. See? Here. These are kaput. It's a complex thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nerve boards?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We use the nervous systems of specially-bred insects to create the electronic circuits on our motherboards. (SMILES) Only Antenna Research has it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow. And where do the batteries go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not kidding. He's a total PR nerd. (TO PIKUL) It ports into you, and you are the power source. Your body, your nervous system. Your energy. When you get tired, run down, it won't run properly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Landry here will finish up the pod-work. Meanwhile... (TO PIKUL) Let's get that nasty bioport out of you and get a nice, fresh one in there. We have guest chalets out back. You're both welcome to stay. Now where did I put my bioport-plug puller..? Here it is. Vinokur hauls out a device that looks like a pair of spring- loaded fire tongs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lie down on that couch and pull up your shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In their chalet, a cozy and inn-like'space, Pikul and Geller examine his new bioport while sitting on one of the chalet's twin beds. The region around the port looks swollen, bruised and tender.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It hurts. I think it's infected.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not infected. It's just excited. It wants action. She attempts to jack her pod into his port using the Y- shaped UmbyCord, but he twists away from her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I really don't think that I want action. Me, I mean. The bearer of the excited bioport. What I want is... not now. Not here. I feel too... too exposed. Geller sighs, then switches into her explaining-the-facts- of-life-to-a-child mode. They are both aware that they are replaying an earlier moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cradling her pod) My baby here has now taken three major hits, one in the church, one in the gas station, and one on the operating table. The only way I can tell if everything's OK - the game's not been contaminated, the pod's not fucked - is to play eXistenZ with somebody friendly. Are you friendly, or are you not? Pikul swallows nervously, then turns his back to Geller so that she can port in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're telling me this thing will run off my body's energy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's how they work. See? You're hummin' along already. Sure enough, he is. Geller deftly twists the second jack into her own bioport and takes a deep breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. eXistenZ. Only from Antenna. Here we go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got a bit of an unfair advantage, don't you? How can I possibly compete with the designer of the system?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You could beat the guy who invented poker, couldn't you? Geller flicks the game-pod nipple, and the chalet begins to melt away around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The chalet melts away and is replaced by a scruffy game store. A lot of kids and strange adults mill around amongst the dusty racks and pinball machines, examining packages of weird games and game devices, muttering secretively to each other, and it is amongst these dull rows of shelves that Pikul and Geller find themselves standing. A cashier works away behind an old-fashioned cash register that sits on a tall counter. The cashier, a gangly, sallow young man, glances at Pikul and Geller suspiciously from time to time. Pikul feels himself', his clothes, moves his arms, his tongue. He feels around behind him but there is no game-pod or UmbyCord in sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was beautiful. I feel... just like me. Is that kind of transition normal, a kind of smooth dissolve from place to place?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Depends on the style of the game. You can get jagged, brutal cuts, slow fades, shimmering little morphs...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is amazing. I had no idea. We... we're still ourselves, but we're in the game. Where are we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's basically a game store I used to hang out in as a kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you serious?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're ported into a game-pod together, remember? eXistenZ has complete access to both our central nervous systems. Its game architecture will be based on our memories, our anxieties, our preoccupations...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you serious?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You keep saying that. (examines a game-pak) Look at this. Games I've never heard of. Biological Father. Hit By A Car. Viral Ecstasy. Chinese Restaurant. (reads pak back) In Viral Ecstasy, you are a virus invading a specific human body. You create ingenious viral strategies to cope with the efforts of the body's immune system to destroy you..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute. That reminds me. What precisely is the goal of the game we're playing now? I mean, the rules, the objective... Nobody's ever really said anything about what you have to do in eXistenZ.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The beauty of eXistenZ is that it changes every time you play it. It adapts to the individuals who are actually playing it. The result is that you have to play the game to find out why you're playing the game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that's kind of cheating, isn't it? Not to say confusing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. It's a much more organic approach to gaming than classic, arbitrary, rule- dominated games. It's the future, Pikul. You'll see how natural it feels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at this. Could this be the future too? (picks up a game-pod) Ever see anything like this before? They are looking at a game-pod in a gel-pak that is even weirder than a tissue-pod. It has a logo and a name -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Suddenly, a hand reaches into the frame and takes the pak away, puts it neatly back on the rack. Pikul and Geller look up at a man in his early fifties, graying, thinning hair, beefy, generally harried and pugnacious air. The man is Dorsey Nader.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These are delicate. You have to be careful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I can imagine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cortical Systematics is the latest and the hottest. Not just a new game, but a new system.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will it work with an industry standard bioport?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (ignores her question) I haven't seen you two before, have I? This is my place. Haimische, isn't it? Funky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're new in town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to Dorsey Nader's Game Emporium. I'm Dorsey Nader. Is there anything I can help you with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're just looking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have what you're looking for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Follow me. Nader turns his back on them and walks to the back of the store. He stops at a warped and dirty door, turns, beckons to them urgently, trying not to be noticed by the preoccupied patrons. As Pikul and Geller follow Nader through the door, they do not escape the notice of the sour-faced young cashier, who writes something down hurriedly on a pad with an air of vengeful self-importance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GAME STORE - NIGHT Pikul and Geller find themselves in a stockroom jammed to overflowing with packaged and naked game-related merchandise. They are alone with Nader, and they are all sitting on wooden crates. Nader rummages on the shelves behind him for a moment, then turns back to them with a gel-pak in his hands. He studies them for a moment, hefting the gel-pak in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who sent you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's none of your businesz who sent us. We're here, and that's all that matters. Pikul is shocked at his own response. He turns to Geller in horror, worried that he's blown the game already.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh God, what happened? I didn't mean to say that!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your character who said it. It's a kind of schizophrenic feeling, isn't it? But you'll get used to it. There are things that have to be said to advance the plot and establish the characters, and those things get said whether you want to say them or not. Don't fight it. Just go with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But should you be saying that in front of him? Nader?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at him. Pikul does. Nader doesn't seem to have heard him. In fact, he doesn't respond at all other than to hum the Antenna Research corporate-song and tap his fingers repetitively, caught in a small behavioural loop. Geller chuckles at Pikul's confusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's gone into a game loop, he's locked up, and he won't come out of it until you give him a proper game line of dialogue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is tricky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Start by repeating your last line. Include his name so he knows you're talking.to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're here, Dorsey Nader, and that's all that matters. Nader immediately comes out of his loop. He chuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. That is all tha matters. Pikul smiles, delighted. Now he takes a deep breath, closes his eyes, relaxes. The line comes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Nader, you said you had what we want. We're waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to need these micro- pods to download your new identities. I assume that you both have had those industry standard bioports you mentioned installed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, of course, that's right. We both have bioports. Here she pauses, looks at Pikul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We do, don't we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I assumed we did. I mean, here. In the game. Of course, we might not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd better check. While Nader goes into game lock-up, Geller lifts up her shirt. Pikul takes a look. Her bioport is there, although slightly rougher, puckered, more organic than in non-game life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, it's there. Looks a little different, but it's there. Geller grabs Pikul's shirt and lifts it. His is there too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see what you mean. (TO NADER) Yes, we both have bioports.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Port in and this'll tell you all you need to know for now. Pikul and Geller examine the pak, which bears the Cortical Systematics name and logo. It seems to be a miniature version of their real-life game-pod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to leave while you finish up here. It wouldn't be good for us all to be seen together. Nader gets up to leave, pauses at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't do anything I wouldn't do. Nader chuckles a very theatrical chuckle, then leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I assume that Nader is our entry point into the game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Kinda disappointing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nader?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Not a very well-drawn character. And his dialogue was just so-so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. (PAUSE) Do we blame ourselves for that? The bad dialogue? Or would it be bad no matter who was ported in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The game engine is just getting used to us. It'll get more daring once it warms up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Geller fumbles the micro-pod out of its vacuum-pak shell. She reads the instructions on the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The pods are so small they plug directly into the bioport. Geller delicately twists the end of the micro-pod into Pikul's bioport. The micro-pod changes colour, pulses, ripples, and then slowly flows and wriggles its way into Pikul's bioport until it has completely disappeared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole pod just disappeared into your back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It disappeared into my back?! It... it's in my spine? It's winding its way around my spinal cord?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't panic, it's just a game. Do you feel anything yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (controlling his fear) No, I don't. Not a thing. I don't feel a thing. Uh, do you want me to do you? They change positions. Pikul ports in the micro-pod and it duly crawls its way into Geller's bioport. Tenderly, as though kissing a cut to make it better, Pikul kisses her back, low near her bioport. Geller whirls around with sudden anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That wasn't me. That was my game character. I wouldn't have done that. Not here, anyway. She pauses, then kisses him on the mouth, hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. Our characters are obviously supposed to jump on each other. Probably to create emotional tension when danger happens. No use fighting it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about our new identities? Do you feel yours yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll take care of themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm very worried about my body. Geller stops, sits up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean, where are our real bodies? Are they all right? Are they hungry? What if there's danger?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (kissing and caressing
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're just where we left them, sitting quietly, eyes closed. Just like meditating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reluctantly kissing and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I feel really vulnerable. Disembodied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't sweat it. All your senses are still operating. You'll pop right out of the game if there's a problem. They begin to make seriously hot love amrngst the game paks and cartons of replacement UmbyCords. And then the game store melts away around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ASSEMBLY LINE - DAY Pikul finds himself sitting at an immensely long bench in the process of assembling insect motherboards along with many other workers. Pikul can still feel the warmth of Geller's body, but she's nowhere to be seen. A gritty, narrow conveyor belt runs down the middle of the bench, upon which floats an endless stream of motherboard parts which the workers pick off as they need them. The belt begins and ends in the anonymous smoky innards of the building. The place, a high-ceilinged pre-fab, long and narrow with hundreds of blanked-out windows, houses a game-pod assembly line. Pikul looks down to find himself wearing a photo-ID card clipped to his shirt pocket that tells him he is somebody named LARRY ASHEN. He has to twist the card around because, of course, from his vantage point it is upside down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tryin' to remember who you are? Pikul snaps his head up to see a long-haired, morose-looking worker sitting next to him, snickering. Mocking Pikul, he twists his own card around, comically bunching up his work shirt so he can read his own name, which is YEVGENY NOURISH.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, it works! I must be Yevgeny Nourish! Nourish leans over to squint at Pikul's name tag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you... you are new to the Trout Farm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I... I'm... very new. Did you say trout farm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know - raise baby trout from eggs and then stock the rivers with them. (BROAD GESTURE) Entire place used to be a trout farm. Seems like most everything used to be something else, doesn't it? Pikul looks around him. The place is humming, but Geller is still nowhere in sight. The workers are small-town locals o_A a wide range of ages. Pikul looks down at his own hands, which seem to,know what to do: place glue on the boards, glue them down to a resin frame using a template, insert needle-like electrodes into the bodies of certain epoxied insects. The insect boards, Pikul notes, are actually whole insects coated in epoxy and frozen together like a sick collage. At least, here in the game they are. Pikul is now automatically doing flashy moves with the odd materials in front of him with great dexterity. Nourish takes note of this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with admiration) You might be new but you seem to know what you're doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It surprises me more than it surprises you. Nourish moves back to the insect motherboard that he has been working on, then leans over again exactly as he did the first time. It has the effect of an instant replay, but not in slow-motion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You might be new but you seem to know what you're doing. Pikul realizes he hasn't given the right answer. He now just lets it come without thinking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ah... I've been trained by the very best. Nourish unlocks and looks around with a delicate furtiveness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So have I. Where do you plan to have lunch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm new here. I have no plans for lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suggest the Chinese restaurant in the forest. Everybody knows where it is. Just ask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Won't you be going there too?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have other plans for lunch. But I do suggest that you order the special. And don't take no for an answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, I'll do that. Nourish turns back to his task and begins to work away as though Pikul didn't exist. Pikul takes this cue to go back to his own board and is soon preoccupied with testing the board's circuits by porting it into a test UmbyCord that uncoils from the center of the bench. His strange reverie, watching himself work on auto- pilot at this bizarre task, is soon interrupted by a worker pushing a canvas and metal cart with bicycle wheels. The worker parks the cart behind Pikul and taps him on the shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They need this in the back room. They asked for you. The worker shuffles off, leaving the cart behind him. Pikul turns to Nourish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It means that they want you in the back room. They need more insect boards for the pod assembly bays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should I just get up and go there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. I'll take care of your incoming boards. Pikul gets up to go. Nourish grabs him by the arm and whispers intensely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember. The Chinese restaurant for lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I order the special.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . POD ASSEMBLY BAYS - DAY Pikul enters the huge back wing of the Trout Farm and walks along a rampway, pushing his cart past the pod assembly-bay area. There, pods very much like the one he and Geller are ported into back home are being assembled - motherboards inserted, internal ports connected, fleshy housings like the corpses of small amphibians sewn up - by small teams of workers. The bays themselves are old horse stalls with straw still covering the dirt floors. But because the pods are primarily organic, the teams are more like groups of masked surgical workers in a series of impossibly small and filthy operating rooms than, let's say, auto-assembly teams in a progressive Saab plant. As Pikul wheels his cart past each stall, he digs into the cart's canvas bag and delivers insect boards wrapped in brown wax paper to the eagerly awaiting pod teams. In the last bay, one of the masked surgeons grabs him by the hand instead of taking the proferred motherboard pnd leads himm to an isolated corner. Her ID card says she is BARB BRECKEN, and her photo says she is Geller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slipping off her mask) I saw you make contact, Larry Ashen. What did the guy on the .l assembly line say to you? Pikul's expression shows that there is a return game line welling up in his mouth, tickling his tongue, perhaps. Perversely, he fights it, but it comes out anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He told me where to have lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A ragged stream of pod-assembly workers trickles along a densely wooded gravel path towards a very un-Chinese Victorian red-brick farmhouse. A small river flows not more than fifty feet from the restaurant, mimicking the movement of the line of workers. The workers all file past a sign on the lawn in front of the building which reads, MONA ZHANG'S BEIJING CUISINE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pikul and Geller are seated at a round Formica-covered table with a lazy Susan serving wheel in the centre of it, all very Mandarin in style. Other workers sit sullenly at their table, wordless, suspicious. A restaurant dog, a mongrel with a lot a heavy, collie-like fur, lies basking in a pane of sunlight. in a corner. The waiter, a young, athletic Chinese man, comes over bringing rice and tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have nice sea bass today. Shall I bring it for everyone? Pikul and Geller exchange a look. Pikul shrugs OK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We want the special. The waiter looks stunned. The others at their table look distressed. The waiter seems to lock up, almost freeze- framed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear me, Chinese waiter? (SLOWLY) We want the special. The waiter unfreezes, smiles grimly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The special is for special occasions. I cannot give you the special.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But this is a special occasion. It's... Pikul pauses, waiting for the proper game line to materialize in his mouth. Finally, it does. He gestures towards Geller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's her birthday. The waiter locks up for a moment, then unfreezes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A birthday is a special occasion. I will therefore bring the special for everybody. The waiter walks away. The others at the table get up and move away, drift over to other tables with occasional furtive backward glances at Pikul and Geller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess the special isn't very popular.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you know, really, don't you? You don't have to guess. I mean, it's your game, your little universe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. You have to understand that, to understand what we've really created with eXistenZ.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're telling me, for example, that you don't know what the special is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Correct. I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or why we ordered it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We ordered it because another game character told you to. That's a clue we can't ignore. But that's just basic games playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to put the game on pause. Geller just looks at him, puzzled. Pikul panics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The game can be paused, can't it? I mean, all games can be paused, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, yeah, but why? What's wrong? Aren't you dying to see what's special about the special?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm feeling a little disconnected from my real life. I'm kind of losing touch with the texture of it, you know what I mean? I mean, I actually think there's an element of psychosis involved here. I mean, I don't know where my body really is, or where reality is, what I've actually done, or not done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a great sign. It means your nervous system is fully engaging with the game architecture. The game is a lot more fun when it starts to feel realer than real.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Pikul stands up and screams at the top of his lungs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: eXistenZ is paused! The Chinese restaurant melts away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guest chalet melts back up around them. Pikul looks around. They are still sitting on the bed, ported into Geller's pod together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did I do that? I guess I did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So how does it feel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your real life. The one you came back for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just sitting here, it feels completely unreal. I'm sure you knew that would happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're stuck now, aren't you? You want to go back to the Chinese restaurant because there's nothing happening here. We're safe. It's boring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Worse than that. I'm not sure here, where we are, is real at all. This feels like the game. And you... you're beginning to t1 feel a bit like a game character to me. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did we really make love to each other?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Definitely not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It feels like we did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our characters did. I'm sure it would be very different if we did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'm actually just like that in real life. You got the real Ted Pikul there, in the stockroom of the game store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you didn't get the real Allegra Geller, I can tell you that. no
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't? She kisses him gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. In real life I tend to lose control. It can get messy. (PAUSE) Let's go back. Pikul looks down at the pod. He flicks the PLAY nipple. The room melts down around them and is replaced by the Chinese restaurant.
